captions.text:
In the entire universe the two greatest scientific
mysteries are first of all the origin of the

universe itself. And second of all the origin
of intelligence. Believe it or not, sitting

on our shoulders is the most complex object
that Mother Nature has created in the known

universe. You have to go at least 24 trillion
miles to the nearest star to find a planet

that may have life and may have intelligence.
And yet our brain only consumes about 20-30

watts of power and yet it performs calculations
better than any large supercomputer. So it's

a mystery. How is the brain wired up? And
if we can figure that out what can we do with
it to enhance our mental capabilities.

When you look at the brain and all the parts
of the brain they don't seem to make any sense

at all. The visual part of the brain is way
in the back, for example. Why is the brain

constructed the way it is? Is this nothing
but an accident of evolution? Well one way

to look at it is through evolution. That is,
the back of the brain is a so-called reptilian

brain. The most ancient primitive part of
the brain that governs balance, territoriality,

mating. And so the very back of the brain
is also the kind of brain that you find in

reptiles. Now when I was a child I would go
to the science museum and look at the snakes

sometimes and they would stare back at me.
And I would wonder, "What are they thinking

about?" Well, I think now I know. What they're
thinking about was, "Is this person lunch?"

Then we have the center part of the brain
going forward and that's a so-called monkey

brain, the mammalian brain. The brain of emotions.
The brain of social hierarchies. And then

finally the front of the brain is the human
brain, especially the prefrontal cortex. This

is where rational thinking is. And when you
ask yourself a question where am I anyway.

The answer is right behind your forehead.
That's where you really are.

Well, I have a theory of consciousness which
tries to wrap it all up together. There've

been about 20,000 or so papers written about
consciousness and no consensus. Never in the

history of science have so many people devoted
so much time to produce so little. Well, I'm

a physicist and when we physicists look at
a mysterious object the first thing we try

to do is to create a model. A model of this
object in space. And then we hit the play

button and run it forward in time. This is
how Newton was able to come up with the theory

of gravity. This is how Einstein came up with
relativity. So I tried to use this in terms

of the human brain and evolution. So what
I'm saying is I have a new theory of consciousness

based on evolution. And that is consciousness
is the number of feedback loops required to

create a model of your position in space with
relationship to other organisms and finally
in relationship to time.

So think of the consciousness of a thermostat.
I believe that even a lowly thermostat has

one unit of consciousness. That is, it senses
the temperature around it. And then we have

a flower. A flower has maybe, maybe ten units
of consciousness. It has to understand the

temperature, the weather, humidity, where
gravity is pointing. And then finally we go

to the reptilian brain which I call level
1 consciousness and reptiles basically have

a very good understanding of their position
in space, especially because they have to

lunge out and grab prey. Then we have level
2 consciousness, the monkey consciousness.

The consciousness of emotions, social hierarchies,
where are we in relationship to the tribe.
And then where are we as humans.

As humans we are at level 3. We run simulations
into the future. Animals apparently don't

do this. They don't plan to hibernate. They
don't plan the next day's agenda. They have

no conception of tomorrow to the best of our
ability. But that's what our brain does. Our

brain is a prediction machine. And so when
we look at the evolution from the reptilian

brain to the mammalian brain to the prefrontal
cortex, we realize that is the process of

understanding our position in space with respect
to others -- that is emotions -- and finally
running simulations into the future.

title: Michio Kaku: Consciousness Can be Quantified

made of electrons, protons, and neutrons and then you have quarks that make 
up protons and neutrons. I mean, WHERE inside of the atoms in our brain is

comments.text:
I think consciousness is impossible to quantify. The number of possible 
mental states may be infinite (representational thoughts and qualia). If 
consciousness itself IS the act of viewing or being mental states, then you 
can always add one more, or change the whole set of states (implications 
for personal identity). Why would we even try to quantify consciousness if 
it is defined by an infinite number or change? The system that "contains" 
consciousness (in our case, the brain) can be simulated, but that doesn't 
translate into knowledge about what personal identity is (that 
self-referential voice which seems to be what we mean by the word 
"consciousness"). We already have a good intuitve grasp of what 
consciousness is. We are conscious. The problem arises when we try to 
reduce consciousness to neural connections etc. in the brain. It's like 
describing a galaxy in terms of quantum mechanics -- or worse. 
Consciousness and mental states may not even be a "thing" in the world of 
empirical facts, and therein lies the irony: Even if we knew every physical 
fact about the brain down to the spin of the last elementary particle -- 
EVERY single fact, we will still only be able to understand what "red" and 
"green" means through first-hand observation and introspection.﻿

No, consciousness cannot be quantified as brains. There is no significance 
to neurons, seaparate areas of the brain doing different things... They're 
all the same basic formation, neurons, there is no working theory of how 
brains produce consciousness and there are loads of evidence contradicting 
brain=mind. Neurons and brains are faculties in which consciousness becomes 
fragmented and inhibited, not produced. There is no major difference 
between the frontal cortex and the visual cortex... Yet, they are 
associated with very different mental aspects... There are people missing 
half their brains, some with virtually no brain mass at all who are 
intelligent and function just fine, terminal lucidity where people with 
virtually deteriorated brains have sudden lucidity of mind and memory. 
Brains get in the way of mental processes, they do not produce them. It 
disrupts the flow of energy, the flow if thought. If you think of the mind 
as a massive wave, the the brain would be a specifically evolved capturer 
and collapser of that specific evolved form of wave. And yes, astral 
projection of the mind has been repeated in experiments and proven a 
reality. We need to be scientists again and start challenging old age 
beliefs, like materialism, and acknowledge new contradicting data. ﻿

comments.text:
+TheRoot Message
Someone i heard? The ideas i have expressed are based on firm Science. What 
part do you think isn't?

Do you disagree that DMT combines with certain receptors in the brain, 
giving an altered state of consciousness and make you trip?  I would say 
this is very well established.

Give someone DMT, and they will trip for a predictable amount of time. Give 
them water, they will not.

Many people, upon sobering up from DMT, will claim they had "Astral 
Projections", Near Death experiences", Psychedelic trips with significant 
messages"  Yada Yada Yada...

This shows us that these experiences are dependent on the DMT, at the very 
least.

Furthermore, we can get other chemicals which produce similar experiences, 
but are different somewhat due to drugs producing different effects and 
different trips...  we can then compare the two or more different 
substances and see brain activity.

What we find is that brain activity in both are rather similar. Certain 
parts of the brain will experience significant decreased activity compared 
with being sober, and others with significant increased activity. This 
shows that it seems that brain activity in certain regions produced from 
particular chemicals produce these altered states of consciousness.

We can then use this information, to predict which parts of the brain are 
responsible for the reactions people call "astral projections" etc...

Through other countless experiments and information collected unrelated to 
drug trips, we have established what general function these parts of the 
brain seem to have, and they seem to correlate strongly with the effects 
they would produce if increased or decreased activity were to happen from 
some chemical. In other words, the theory has predictive capabilities, 
which is essential in establishing its validity. Coincidence?  I think 
not...

This is well established Neuroscience / Psychology, i'm sorry to say. And 
the further we study this, the further we seem to understand this process 
and how drugs can trick people into having profound experiences which they 
may claim is "beyond this world".

There is definitely more to learn, but this is the best explanations we 
have and it is based on countless experiments and our modern understanding 
of the brain.

Some random dude on the internet saying he thinks there actually is more to 
this material life is just frivolous testimonial and doesn't compare with 
actual modern understanding of the brain through science.

comments.text:
Can I just say something? Please only use Michio Kaku and other 
"documentary" physicists as inspiration and introductions to a subject--do 
not take their analogies as fact, or as realistic representations of the 
mathematical models and sciences behind the theories. Upon questioning both 
my college physics professors regarding Michio Kaku's representations and 
analogies, they shook their heads and told me flat-out that what he's on 
about all the time is this sugar-coated, overly simplified version of 
physics.

So when Michio Kaku is openly declaring that time travel is possible, and 
multiverses are a fundamental doctrine of string theory, and that 
warp-holes could become reality in about a hundred years, or that he can 
theoretically build you a lightsaber--please keep in mind that in order for 
you to actually grasp what's going on here, you need about 8-9 years of 
physic. Advanced physics (often with heavy calculus and 
transcendental/linear algebra). If you don't have that, then please don't 
be an anus and crap over everyone about how science trumps all or that it 
has these magnificent properties or answers. Let's get real. 99% of the 
cow-brained atheists on this website couldn't tell their Gauss' Law from 
their Faraday Law, let alone Maxwell's equations. OR your religion. For 
Pete's sake please shut the f*** up about your religion. If you really 
believed in it enough you wouldn't be quibbling about it on YouTube.﻿

comments.text:
+jim jones The human brain works very differently from a computer brain, 
not just "better or worse". In the downside, the human brain doesn't seem 
to have as much storage space as a computer. So whenever it comes to 
acquiring stored information, we humans are forced to access information 
externally rather than from inside our own brain.

On the goodside, our human brain has about the same memory as a computer 
with 2.5 Petabytes (2.500000 GB) of RAM. So we don't need to store as much 
information either. It's stored in memory in bits and pieces and combined 
to produce the information we need.

Neurons are also far better than transistors at communicating with 
eachother. So when you're saying that a computer can run "hundreds of 
processes" simultaneously, I'm not particularly impressed.

Also process is not the same as a physical action done with a physical 
body. It doesn't matter what you're programmed to do, if you don't have a 
body that can obey that program.

Furthermore, it's been stated several times that the work that the Mars 
Rovers do in weeks on mars for instance, can be done in minutes or hours by 
humans. The reason why we don't send humans (yet) is strictly because of 
maintenance costs. Food and protection.

Not to mention the ludicrously bad AI that exists today, that at best 
behaves like a brain-damaged toddler, unless we're talking about game mobs 
who's been programmed to fake a higher intelligence than they actually have.

Also, my original point wasn't even about what is true right now. It was 
asking about what's true across a given timeline.

Finally, I think half the women on this planet (and the men who's learned 
it) would be very disappointed in you, if you told them that we humans have 
almost no multitasking capability.

planning ahead goes, mice are actually ahead of us. Humans are rarely

something that reduces pain and maximizes physical satisfaction. Our

comments.text:
+Benny Schmidt
I love how everything that doesn't suit your personal beliefs is "silly", 
regardless of how much mainstream science supports it.

The reason cancer cells are immortal, that is, that they are not subject to 
the Hayflick's limit, is because of a substance called "Telomerase". 
Scientists have already found a way to produce this substance, which can be 
used to remove the Hayflick limit in humans.

Considering that the Hayflick limit is what's responsible for most, if not 
all, of aging-related symptoms, from saggy skin, slow healing of wounds, to 
having weak bones, and being generally weakened, it wouldn't be an 
exaggeration to say that the Hayflick limit IS mortality. It is the one 
true guarantee that nearly every animal (save for a certain type of 
jellyfish), no matter how well it is taken care of, will eventually die. 
Therefore, the removal thereof is immortality. It means transcending the 
limits of age.

However, as noted, the removal of the Hayflick limit results in the 
production of cancer cells. This is the primary reason why application of 
telomerase in humans is not recommended. While it can reverse aging, like a 
fountain of youth of sorts, it would also almost inevitably cause the 
formation of cancer cells in the process.

The statement you quoted me saying is correct. There are cells that do not 
suffer from aging-related deterioration, that is, they are not subject to 
the Hayflick limit. They are cancer cells. And scientists have already 
discovered a way to engineer them within humans using telomerase. So, which 
part of my statement, exactly, was wrong?
(Let alone "silly", as you tend to call Nobel-prize winning scientific 
discoveries)

It's nice that you're reading up on the Hayflick limit enough to post 
quotes. Too bad you're not paying enough attention to consider what it 
actually means.

One last thing: "a complete neglect for common sense"

+Saar Korren said, "They've even discovered a way to engineer cells that do 
not suffer from aging-related deterioration, so-called "immortal cells". 
And science even has a name for such cells. They are commonly called 
"cancer cells"."

Cancer cells weren't engineered, they emerge, and "immortal cell lines" 
doesn't mean immortal in the sense that they transcend all mortality. 
Obviously you can kill a cancer cell with radiation or cutting off 
blood-flow to it, so it's not immortal. Also, humans die from cancer, so 
that has nothing to do with the human immortality that +El Idrissi Yasser was

From http://67-20-95-176.bluehost.com/Hayflick.NatureNotImmortal.pdf

"This concept, which was
almost entirely forgotten by the time Hayflick
began his work, was later challenged by the
French Nobel-prize-winning surgeon Alexis
Carrel, who suggested that all cells explanted
in culture are immortal, and that the lack of
continuous cell replication was due to ignorance on how best to cultivate

"Biologists chose the word "immortal" to designate cells that are not 
subject to the Hayflick limit, the point at which cells can no longer 
divide due to DNA damage or shortened telomeres. Prior to Leonard 
Hayflick's theory, Alexis Carrel hypothesized that all normal somatic cells 
were immortal.[3]"

A few scientists arguing over semantics, culminating in a book titled *The 
Immortal Cell* is not anything to run wild with in terms of human 
immortality. 

If I was interested in biological immortality, I would take up more 
interest in the lobster or jellyfish than in cancer.
comments.author: Benny Schmidt

comments.text:
+Christopowaaa
The idea is to test the abilities of both to solve a range of problems, 
with all elements not directly related to independent brain function being 
eliminated, and then comparing the results in terms of successful 
solutions, and time to achieve a solution.

There can be some issues in defining what are "elements not directly 
related to independent brain function". For instance, relative to its size, 
a mouse would have better land speed traversing through a maze, compared to 
a human traveling a scaled-up version of the same maze. A human using 
written or verbal clues in human language would have a clear unfair 
advantage over a mouse which doesn't use the same language (and, possibly, 
no language at all). On a less obvious level, any information a human has 
learned during his life time could pose an unfair advantage, just as 
allowing a mouse to pre-memorize a maze would equally be unfair. Also, 
visual clues may be received differently by humans and mice, due to 
different eye configuration. A mouse could also rely more on scent than a 
human would tend to do. And, obviously, as I've stated before, motivation 
is also a factor, as both the mouse and the human must be equally motivated 
to actually solve the problem involved.
Eliminating every single such factor, at least to the point where remaining 
factors are negligible, does require some careful planning and work.

Once all such factors are eliminated, then, and only then, can you compare 
intelligence, simply as the ability to reach correct solutions to similar 
(read: isomorphic) problems at higher speed. This is how Alan Turing 
defined intelligence, and is pretty much to how Michio Kaku is defining 
"Conciousness" in the above video.
comments.author: Saar Korren

comments.text:
+Saar Korren - To my knowledge, you are scientifically correct with the 
majority your statements. However, your definition of intelligence is 
incorrect. 
Intelligence is quantified by the ability to acquire & apply knowledge. 
Mice & humans use different methods when acquiring & applying knowledge to 
complete tasks such as traversing a maze. Applying the methods mice use to 
humans & concluding that mice are more intelligent, based upon theorising 
an experiment that explicitly favours the mouse, does not seem like a fair 
conclusion to me. However, I am more than willing to be persuaded & 
enlightened on this subject!
Humans acquire & apply knowledge differently to mice, meaning that when 
using methods that favour the human, the human will appear more intelligent 
than the mice. The opposite is also true for the mouse. But if both humans 
& mice achieve the same result using different methods, is one conclusively 
more intelligent than the other? Of course one is more intelligent with 
regards to their preferred method, but outside of that, can you 
conclusively say that one is more intelligent than the other, based upon 
the definition of intelligence I have stated?
comments.author: Christopowaaa

comments.text:
+Benny Schmidt
What you're trying to argue here is paramount to saying that people don't 
age. Or die. Or that death even exists. Your attempt to redefine death as 
anything other than "the cessation of biological activities" is, quite 
frankly, pathetic. Life and death has little to do with energy states.

Even if a person is placed in a sterile environment, regularly fed, and 
never receives any external harm, that person would STILL DIE. Even if 
there was a miracle cure for all ailments, and a perfect treatment for 
cancer, this would not change. The person's cells would simply reach their 
telomer end-life, and then the person would suffer from organ failure. Even 
if the person was somehow kept artificially alive, the person would simply 
reach the point in which every original cell had died.

Cancer, however, WOULD NOT. If you keep it regularly fed, and don't subject 
it to any external trauma or lethal radiation, it would live forever. It 
would remain active and feeding and replicating, forever. Obviously, if you 
toss it into a black hole, it would die. But if you don't intentionally 
cause it harm (and please don't make this debate any more philosophical by 
going "And what if I accidentally cause it harm?"), or starve it, it would 
not. THAT is immortality.
comments.author: Saar Korren

comments.text:
+Saar Korren I'm not debating that scientists said it (if by scientists, 
you mean the author of *The Immortal Cell* and his cohorts who coined the 
term), I'm debating the semantics -- why use the word "immortal" other than 
to attract extra attention to the process?

Furthermore, if you set aside "physical damage", then *everything* is 
immortal. All energetic configurations naturally decay over time, but the 
energy is never destroyed. When we say something "dies", we really mean 
that its specific energetic or chemical configuration falls apart and 
energy dissipates into other configurations. Of course if you remove the 
possibility of "physical damage" (or, physical interactions which result in 
the whole or partial destruction of the configuration), then the 
configuration will be preserved, but that can also be achieved with other 
means like freezing a biological cell at absolute zero -- it doesn't mean 
that biological cells are "immortal", it just means that they're incredibly 
stable in certain environments, and slightly unstable in others, such that 
they naturally decay over time. 

A cancer cell can die due to failure of an organelle caused by radioactive 
exposure, causing the cell's processes to corrupt or otherwise fail.  

A human being can die due to failure of an organ caused by cancer 
proliferation, causing the organ's processes to corrupt or otherwise fail. 

So, neither are "immortal" in the sense that they transcend mortality and 
result in an eternal configuration or process.

comments.text:
+El Idrissi Yasser
Well, setting aside the whole conspiracy theory stuff (If you want to 
believe that, suit yourself), there's the point where you say you agree 
with everything I've said, after spending 20+ lines (With no paragraph 
breaks, sheesh. And you seem to dislike the use of the period as well) 
saying the exact opposite of everything I said.

I'll give a tangible example, so it doesn't sound like I'm just throwing 
stuff in the air. You've said "if a man was to be freed from all boundaries 
of society, he would ultimately find his genius one way or another". But 
I've clearly explained that most tangible accomplishments, or even mundane 
tasks, done by humans were the result of humans living in a society made of 
and by humans. My claim was clearly that if you take a human away from the 
company of other humans, he would become hapless and incompetent, the polar 
opposite of "genius". Rather, it would allow his inner moron to thrive.
I have no illusion about lasting more than a few minutes away from the 
comfort of my home, built by other people, and the technology within it, 
also made by other people. A human without other humans is like a fish 
without water.

I'll also provide a tangible example for the above. Imagine if a human was 
given a doohickey, and was told that operating it would provide him with a 
sum of money. The person would look for the instructions, ask other people, 
check on Google, etc. In a sterile room, with no other humans, no methods 
of communication, and no prior training or experience in how to operate 
said doohickey or similar such, a human would have issues simply "figuring 
it out" alone.
Now switch the human up with a mouse, and place some cheese inside the 
doohickey instead of cash. Even if other mice are present, mice don't have 
a concept of language at a level that allows them to pool together their 
brain power. A mouse certainly can't read instructions, and most definitely 
can't search for a solution on Google. The mouse would have "figuring it 
out alone" as the go-to solution. However, having no other tools to turn 
to, allows mice to be specialists in "figuring it out alone". The mouse 
would poke, and prod, and experiment, and eventually figure it out. And it 
would accomplish this in less time than a human would.

comments.text:
I had an experience on Ketamine once. It completely changed how I view 
conciousness altogether. It made me realise that the everyday reality that 
we find ourselves in is only one state or 'mode' of conciousness, and is 
most certainly *not* the only concious state available to us. When I took 
Ketamine it activated thoughts and emotions I had no idea I was capable of. 
I viewed 'myself' as if I was observing another person. There was a real 
sense of peaceful detachment in looking at my own life as if viewing it 
from the perspective of somebody else. I felt that the universe was this 
gigantic, expansive void stretching into infinity in all directions, 
sparsely peppered with minuscule pockets of order and activity, and there I 
was, sat in a small room, in a tiny, unimportant corner of this vast cosmic 
arena (to borrow a few words from Sagan) that is our universe. The people 
around me were suddenly as much part of the universe as the stars in the 
night sky. My vision was stuttered and choppy, and noises became echoed and 
erratic. The people around me became more like clockwork, they *were* the 
Cosmos itself going through the actions of concious behaviour, as if it was 
all automated.﻿

I'll have to do some research (although not that much research can be done 
from that far back, right? haha)

+mittenengrey well, we're all mammal and animals... wolf packs and the like 
are the first thing I thought of when he mentioned it, though.

That said, I think mitten has a point. If we accept natural selection as 
the means that determines reproduction, the act of finding a mate and 
reproducing is all about determining dominance as a more 'primitive' form 
of a hierarchy. Android, on the other hand, seems to be referring to an 
authority structure of a hierarchy, which would be similar to government 
(and organized communities, maybe?). But if we do look at it from an 
animalistic perspective, there's a social hierarchy throughout many species 
that defines us as social animals, or needing others to help survive and 
thrive. This seems to bring up an interesting situation of whether we are 
social by nature or whether we became social as we became more intelligent. 
I don't know. Any thoughts?
